description.narrative:
Kambodja inledde år 2004 en reform med syfte att stärka den offentliga finansiella styrningen (OFS). Reformen har finansierats av flera givare, däribland EU och Sida. I december 2015 fattade EU-kommissionen beslut om att lämna fortsatt stöd till reformen. Beslutet innebär stöd genom två olika finansieringsmekanismer; sektorbudgetstöd till reformens genomförande samt en delegering till Sida för att finansiera insatser som kompletterar sektorbudgetstödet. Det svenska stödet kommer att riktas till aktörer/områden som inte i tillräcklig omfattning inkluderats i tidigare stöd till OFS-reformen, och som inte med automatik kan nås via EU:s sektorbudgetstöd. Lärdomar från tidigare stöd visar att de mest relevanta områdena för additionellt och riktat stöd handlar om anti-korruption, externrevision, statistik och extern granskning av budgeten. Dessutom har betydelsen av att öka skatteintäkterna och effektiviteten i skatteadministrationen understrukits.
Det svenska stödet kommer att omfatta följande kambodjanska myndigheter och organisationer: Statistikmyndigheten, Skattemyndigheten, Transparency International Cambodia, Riksrevisionen och Parliamentary Institute of Cambodia. Den totala budgeten för det program som ska genomföras av Sida, Partnership for Accountability and Transparency (PAT), är 10,342 miljoner euro. EU:s bidrag uppgår till 7 miljoner euro. Det svenska bidraget uppgår till ca 32 miljoner kronor.
Denna insats avser stöd till samarbete mellan den kambodjanska skatteadministrationen, General Department of Taxation (GDT) och svenska Skatteverket. Ett samarbete påbörjades i augusti 2015 som resulterade i en projektansökan till Sida för stöd till institutionssamarbete inom områdena service till skattebetalare, införande av ett system för personlig inkomstbeskattning och ökad effektivitet inom kontantsektorn för perioden 1 juli 2016 till 30 juni 2019.
Insatsen bedöms vara relevant i förhållande till både svenska och kambodjanska strategier och policies och partnerna bedöms ha tillräcklig kapacitet och kompetens för att uppnå de förväntade resultaten. Det förslås att GDT och STA erhåller ett stöd om EUR 1 421 000 samt SEK 6 450 000 för perioden juli 2016 till juni 2019.
Tax Cooperation 2016-2019 with the Cambodian tax authority to build capacity for a more effective tax system, including a personal income tax.

The General Department of Taxation (GDT) is the main revenue collection agency in Cambodia. It is regulated by the Law on Taxation, and is one of twelve departments under the MEF. Increased revenue mobilization is important in order to increase the fiscal space for government reforms and over time reduce aid dependency and is therefore a key component of Cambodia’s PFM reform. Significant increases in domestic revenue mobilization in the past few years (from 14.77% of GDP in 2013 to 18.39% of GDP in 2016 and 25.05% in 2019) have allowed increasing government allocations to the social sectors. For example, the national recurrent expenditure of the education sector between the years of 2013-2017 has increased by 112%. Nonetheless, tax compliance is low and leakages are high. Therefore, strengthening oversight and accountability of tax institutions and promoting transparency are critical to improve the performance and credibility of tax institutions. The overall objective of the intervention is strengthened mobilization of domestic revenue through three outcome areas: 1) Expanded coverage of taxpayers and increased effectiveness of tax collection2) Improved transparency of taxpayers’ obligations, liabilities and rights through improved taxpayers service3) Development of a coherent personal income tax (PIT) The focus of the programme is to promote voluntary compliance, increase overall revenue collection and promote fewer and more equitable application of the revenue laws. A main principle is that when a system or organisation is perceived as transparent, accountable and trustworthy by the public, the people is more willing to comply.

description.narrative: This institutional cooperation between GDT and the Swedish Tax Agency (STA) started in June 2016. The intervention is co-funded by EU and Sida and forms one part of the Partnership for Accountability and Transparency programme. The current reporting period reflects progress made during the three and a half year of cooperation. There are three main outcomes in the work plan for the final year of PAT I, 2019: 1) risk management and cash sector; 2) taxpayer service; and 3) personal income tax. On risk management and cash sector, the General Risk Overview was updated for the first time with the involvement of all GDT departments and inclusion of new statistics and thus the Compliance Risk Management process has continued. The number of registered taxpayers has gone from 29 700 in 2016 to 50 800 in 2018 and 64 900 in 2019, showing a steady improvment. Revenue collection has increased from USD 1 502 million in 2016 to USD 2 819 million in 2019. However, STA is careful to causally link this to project activities since planned pilots were not conducted and baselines to measure effects do not exist. Regarding the Taxpayer Service, in the end of 2019, the Call Center responded to 60 809 chats or calls, which is almost 40 000 more than in 2018 or an increase by 166%. Surveys show that in the end of 2019, the satisfaction of taxpayers in contact with the Call Center regarding the content was 98% and appreciation of the agents behaviour reached 99 %. In the end of 2019, the Taxpayer's Service component, moreover, conducted a training in voluntary compliance, communication and attitudes for heads of all Tax Branches and Departments. Many participants pointed out that this training is an important tool for increasing the trust for the tax administration and thus for voluntary compliance. In 2019, the Ministry of Finance and Economy decided to postpone the introduction of a Personal Income Tax (PIT) and decided to introduce the Capital Gain Tax (CGT). The CGT is not part of the PIT indicator and will affect the result tracking of the programme. There are however advantages for starting with the CGT, as the public more gradually would be introduced to the idea of personal taxation and experiences from the launch of CGT could be applied to the PIT later. During 2019, there have been efforts between GDT and NIS (National Statistics Office) to agree on a framework for sharing information. This work will as well continue during the second phase of the PAT-programme.
